title: 113_hr1635
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Commission on Federal Marijuana Policy Act of 2013". Since 1971, the Shafer Commission recommended decriminalizing marijuana, but the Federal Government has continued its "War on Drugs." Some states have legalized marijuana for medicinal use, and others have decriminalized it since 1973. Since 1973, 15 states have decriminalized marijuana for personal use, and 2 states have legalized and regulated it. The Federal Government has not reviewed its policy towards marijuana since the Shafer Commission. There is a need for the Federal Government to address the conflict between its prohibition of marijuana and the laws of states where it is legal. The National Commission on Federal Marijuana Policy is established to address the conflict between federal prohibition of marijuana and state laws where it is legal. The Commission will review Federal policies on marijuana in light of state legalization for medicinal or personal use, considering interactions with state laws, costs of prohibition, potential regulation and taxation, banking and tax impacts on businesses, health effects compared to alcohol and tobacco, and public safety implications. The Commission will review the impact of marijuana prohibition on public safety, criminal justice, racial disparities, and international relationships. It will also consider recommending the appropriate placement of marijuana in the Controlled Substances Act. The Commission will review the impact of marijuana prohibition on public safety, criminal justice, racial disparities, and international relationships, and consider recommending the appropriate placement of marijuana in the Controlled Substances Act. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 13 members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. The Commission consists of 13 members appointed by different officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, and minority leader of the Senate. Two members are appointed by the minority leader of the Senate based on qualifications in criminal justice, public health, social policy, economics, or international law. Disqualifications include personal financial interests or holding public office. The Commission consists of 13 members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, and minority leader of the Senate. Members serve for life and must be appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members receive level V of the Executive Schedule as basic pay and travel expenses. Each member of the Commission appointed by various officials receives travel expenses, including per diem, in accordance with applicable provisions. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission shall meet as called by the co-chairs or majority of members, with the first meeting within 60 days of enactment. A quorum of seven members is required for business, while two members suffice for receiving testimony. Meetings are open to the public for interested persons to present statements. The Commission may hold public hearings in various states where marijuana is legal for different purposes. They may establish panels to carry out their work. Meetings must be preceded by public notice in the Federal Register. The Commission may establish panels with less than full membership, but their findings are not official unless approved by the Commission. Members, agents, or staff can take actions authorized by the co-chairs. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The administration of the Commission may establish panels with less than full membership, and their findings require approval by the Commission. Members, agents, or staff can take actions authorized by the co-chairs. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission may appoint a Director at level V of the Executive Schedule, who can appoint additional personnel without following standard appointment procedures. The Director can also hire experts and consultants as needed. The Commission, under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, can request Federal agency personnel to assist without reimbursement, maintain their civil service status, obtain official data from government departments, use the U.S. mails, and enter into contracts. The Commission is authorized to enter contracts with various entities for its duties, accept gifts, and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within a year of receiving funds, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting the report. $10,000,000 is authorized for this Act, with a limitation on using funds for international travel.
